Kanesane swords do have a fairly good following for a showato in part thank=
s to the Fuller and Gregory=A0book and the fact that most were water quench=
ed. A broken tip unfortunately=A0will require a foundation polish making it=
 difficult to get away with anything short of a costly polish and a=A0good =
polisher.=A0
=A0
regards, Franco

Date: Thursday, February 19, 2009, 7:30 PM







Hello:

I recently =
acquired a sword blade ONLY at a yard sale. From what I can tell 
it was ma=
de around 1943ish by Asano Kanasane I have attached a picture of what 
I ha=
ve found on reference. The Mei is to me an exact match of example "C". 

Th=
ere is a small chip on the Ho, that is almost not viewable but it is 
"feel=
able" as well as several parry marks on the Mune. The very end of the Kissa=
ki 
(approx 1/16") is broken off.

From the sources I have found this blade=
 was very probably a showato sword 
made for the Japanese Army. There are n=
o other mounts or anything.

Now I know this isn't a "real collectable" but=
 for the "investment" I made I 
feel that it would be worth a decent polish=
 as I can see a great deal of 
activity along the Hamon even through the ve=
ry light oxidation on the blade..

I will send some photos once I get them =
taken (my photographic skills are 
marginal at best) if there is any intere=
st. My skills lay more in the 
metalworking end of things...

SO if anyone =
on the list is interested in helping out an old hammerhead I 
would appreci=
ate it..

JPH 

Dr JP Hrisoulas, COL NANG (Ret)
